The management measures enforced in Bass Strait by the States and the Commonwealth, are included in the table accompanying the article " Fisheries Management in Australia " on pages 21-23 of "Fisheries Newsletter ' for February, 1962. I am arranging for a copy to be made available to the honorable member.
No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Navy, upon notice -

item.para: Has H.M.A.S. "Supply" left the United Kingdom for Australia?
Is it a fact that this vessel, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping, was built as a fleet tanker in 1955 and named "Tide Austral"?
Was the vessel, as " Tide Austral ", manned by merchant seamen?
Have the Royal Navy and the Royal Australian Navy always manned vessels of this type with officers and men from the Merchant Navy?

If the position is as stated, will the Minister state whether this vessel will be manned by Australian Merchant Navy personnel as was the case with former Australian vessels such as the " Biloela " and the " Karumba "?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for the Navy has supplied the following information: -

item.para: Yes- Department 1st October, 1962.
Yes.
Yes.

The vessels which the Royal Australian Navy has used in the past as Fleet Auxiliaries have been manned by officers and men of the Merchant Navy. As far as is known the Royal Navy has followed a similar policy.
H.M.A.S. " Supply " is and will be manned by officers and men of the Royal Australian Navy.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Has the Government any proposals for the decentralization of industry throughout the nation, and particularly in Queensland?
Is it a fact that the concentration of industry and population in the capital cities is to the detriment of the development of other areas of the nation?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's questions is as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: For the Government's general position on decentralization, I refer the honorable member to my reply in to-day's " Hansard " to a question on the subject by the honorable member for Bendigo. The Government's interest in this matter is readily discernible from the efforts it has made over the years to assist, in numerous ways, the process of development of the nation as a whole. These efforts have been greatly stepped up in recent years by the large sums devoted by the Government to assistance towards various major developmental projects and activities, particularly in the north of Australia. Among the projects and activities of a developmental nature, for which the Commonwealth is providing funds, those in Queensland, already in train or in prospect, hold a prominent place. The large expenditure already proceeding on the Mount Isa railway, on the construction of beef cattle roads, and on coal-loading facilities at Gladstone Harbour, are cases in point. This year's Budget provides for assistance in financing the first stages of a scheme to open up and develop to full production a vast area of the rich brigalow lands in the Fitzroy Basin of central Queensland, as well as for additional funds for the sealing of roads included in the beef cattle road construction programme referred to. The Government's decision to double the funds available in 1962-63 for oil search subsidies may also be expected, in the light of the discoveries of oil at Cabawin and Moonie, to have beneficial results for the programme of oil exploration in Queensland.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice-

item.para: Has he received a request from a country industries conference held at Wangaratta seeking a national inquiry into the means of securing a more balanced development and distribution of industry and population in Australia?
If so, has he considered or replied to the request?
If not, in view of the support given last year by both Country Party and Australian Labour Party members to a motion urging the setting up of such an inquiry, will he accede to this request?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: I have not received such a request.

Decentralization measures lie within the constitutional province of the States. However, within the limits of the possibilities constitutionally open to it, the Commonwealth is doing a great deal to achieve the more balanced growth and distribution of industry and population in Australia. In particular, the large sums now being expended by the Commonwealth on developmental projects and in assistance to such activities as the gold-mining industry and the search for oil are promoting development in outlying parts of the Commonwealth, especially in the north and the north-west, in the most direct possible manner. In so doing, the Commonwealth is helping to provide employment on the spot in areas where opportunities for additional employment are not always easy to find. In a more general sense, the Commonwealth's taxation policies in respect of rural industry materially support the principle of decentralization. An incentive to the establishment of population in non-urban areas and to the development of rural industry is provided by the special taxation concessions made available to primary producers. These include the outright deduction in the year in which they are incurred of certain classes of capital expenditure and special depreciation at the rate of 20 per cent, per annum allowed in respect of most types of equipment and machinery as well as to structural improvements. A similar incentive of more general application is also provided through the system of zone allowances incorporated in the taxation law.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice -

quote.para: Will he prepare and distribute to honorable members a detailed statement outlining the possible effects upon the specific Australian industries, and Australian trade generally, if Britain should enter the European Economic Community without obtaining a continuance of Commonwealth preferences?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows: -

quote.para: In my speeches in this chamber on 3rd May and 30th August this year, I dealt with this subject in some detail. The Prime Minister also referred to it in his speech on 9th August. It is not proposed to issue a statement along the lines suggested by the honorable member at present.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice -

item.para: What is Australia's annual export income?
How much of the total is paid to foreign shipping and insurance companies?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The total value of Australia's exports in 1961-62 was £1,078,000,000.
None. This figure represents the value of exports f.o.b. at ports of shipment. Shipping and insurance charges for transportation overseas would be additional costs to the overseas importers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice -

item.para: Does the annual report of the Australian Meat Board show that since 19SS overseas shipping freights have increased by 62 per cent, on beef, 40 per cent. on lamb and 34 per cent. on mutton?
Is he able to say whether these increases were justified, and are they having a detrimental effect upon Australia's meat trade overseas?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: Yes.

The freight rates and terms of contracts operating for exports of wool, meat, dairy products, fruit and general cargo from Australia to United Kingdom and the Continent are determined by agreement between representatives in Australia of overseas shipping companies in the Conference and specified representative groups of Australian producers and shippers of these goods. Changes in freight rates are based on accepted variations in the cost to shipowners of operating the service. The Australian Meat Board is represented on the Committee of producers and shippers who negotiate levels of freight rates with the shipowners. Although production is governed by many factors notably seasonal variations, Australian total exports of chilled, frozen and canned meats have risen from 195,000 tons in 1954-55 to 290,500 tons in 1961-62.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that some Japanese imports are arriving in Australia packed in cases and crates which are riddled with borers?
If so, what action has been taken, or is proposed to be taken, to correct this state of affairs?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: Boring insects are found in some of the packing cases and crates used for imports from most countries. The incidence in cases and crates from Japan is no higher than elsewhere'.

There is close co-operation between officers of Departments of Health and Customs and Excise in the detection of borer infestation in imported packages. Any such infestation is dealt with either by fumigation or heat treatment or if necessary, destruction to remove the danger.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Has the report submitted to the London College of Physicians, wherein cigarette smoking was declared to be a cause of lung cancer, been examined by the Commonwealth Department of Health?
Do the Commonwealth health authorities endorse the finding contained in this report?
If so, what arethe details of any proposed action by the Government arising from this decision?
Can the Minister state what action was taken by the British authorities following the release of the report?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Yes.
The recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council are substantially in accord with those contained in the British report.

The advertising of cigarettes is at present under consideration by an expert committee of the council. Most of the State health education councils, in association witheducation departments are conducting publicity campaigns emphasizing the dangers of acquiring the smoking habit.
Action taken by the British authorities seems to have been directed mainly towards publicity campaigns and restriction of advertising.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to a recent statement by Professor Richard Lovell, professor of medicine at the Melbourne University, that advertisements for new drugs appearing in the " Australian Medical Journal " are sometimes ridiculous and possibly misleading or dangerous?
Was thalidomide advertised and sold under the trade name of Distaval?
Was this drug widely prescribed as a valuable sedative for expectant mothers?
Was it subsequently proved to have caused some deformities in babies?
What information is the Minister able to supply regarding the extent and the effect of the use of thalidomide in Australia?
What action does the Government intend to take to protect the Australian public against the type of advertising to which Professor Lovell has directed attention?
What steps does the Government propose to take to see that new drugs are properly tested before being made available for general use?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Yes.
Yes.
This drug was prescribed in Australia for expectant mothers, but not widely.
Yes.
This is being investigated in collaboration with State health authorities.
The Commonwealth Government has no control over the publication of advertisements for either new or old drugs in professional journals.
The question of the testing of new drugs is under consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement made by Mr. J.L. Craddock, Sydney city coroner, at a recent inquest into the death of a woman, wherein he suggested that the appropriate authorities consider strictly controlling or prohibiting the use of the drug Amidopyrin?

Has the Commonwealth Government taken any action, either directly or in conjunction with the States, to have this question urgently and thoroughly examined, with a view, if found necessary, to action being taken on a national scale?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Yes.

Discussions will be held between Commonwealth and State health authorities when the Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council meets later this month. The form, content, availability and unrestricted consumption of analgesics will be examined.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that tranquillizers containing the drug Carbromal are causing insanity?
Can these tranquilizers be purchased without a prescription under well-known trade names?
If so, what are these trade names, and is any action being taken to prevent the sale of these drugs without a doctors' prescription?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Over use of sedatives containing Carbromal has been reported as a cause of drug addiction.
Yes - except in Queensland.

There are a number of preparations on sale which contain the drug Carbromal. I shall forward to the honorable member a list of the preparations containing Carbromal known to my advisers. Any action to prevent the sale of these preparations without a doctor's prescription in the States is a matter for the State governments. In the Australian Capital Territory preparations containing Carbromal may be sold without a prescription, but only on the signing of a poisons' register.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

quote.para: Why did the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee restrict the classes of patients for whom the drug largactil may be prescribed as a pharmaceutical benefit?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

quote.para: In accordance with its usual practice, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee took into account all relevant considerations, including the therapeutic efficacy of the drug for various classes of patients, before making its recommendation. The honorable member will be interested to learn that steps are being taken to introduce a procedure designed to make it easier for exhospital patients to obtain their maintenance supplies of largactil. I have sought the advice of State Ministers for Health concerning the proposed change, and it is hoped that the new procedure will commence in the near future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister represent ing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Will the Minister supply a list of hospitals in New South Wales recognized by the Commonwealth Department of Health for Special Account purposes at the 30th September, 1962?
What conditions are necessary to qualify a hospital or convalescent home for recognition for Special Account purposes?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: The recognition of hospitals for Special Account purposes is continuously under review and because the continual alterations would render lists misleading it is not the practice to supply them. Advice as to the recognition status of any hospital is available from the Commonwealth Director of Health, 39 York-street, Sydney. Currently, there are 382 recognized hospitals in New South Wales.

The National Health Act provides that benevolent homes, convalescent homes, homes for aged persons and rest homes cannot be recognized for Special Account purposes. In determining whether a hospital shall be recognized or not for Special Account purposes, a comparison is made between the standards of the hospital and the standards generally prevailing in recognized public hospitals. The main points to which attention is directed are the standard of accommodation generally, the standard of the clinical equipment, the ration between the bed capacity and the number of trained nurses on the staff and, most importantly, the class of patient usually accommodated.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice -

item.para: How many farms on King Island and in the Togari, Mawbanna and Meunna districts of Tasmania have now been assessed by the Commonwealth and State Committee of Inquiry on war serviceland settlement?
What is the total amount of credit given to settlers in respect of each of these settlement areas?
How many acres of redevelopment have now been completed in each area following the committee's recommendation?
What total area in each case has been sanctioned by the committee for redevelopment?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: King Island, 115; Mawbanna, 11; Togari and Meunna, nil.
King Island, £198,272 14s. 8d; Mawbanna, £41,141 12s. 8d.; Togari and Meunna, nil.
King Island, 3,361 acres; Mawbanna, 80 per cent. of clearing completed; Togari and Meunna, nil.

The total area of redevelopment approved by the Closer Settlement Board and the Commonwealth Land Settlement Authority to date is - King Island, 11,104 acres; Mawbanna, 199 acres; Togari and Meunna, nil.

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a tact that at the time Australia installed the automatic telegraph system Tress, no postal administration of any country had thought the system good enough to buy?

Was this system then used only by its originator, the Western Union Telegraph Company of the United States, and were reports received from that country that the system did not offer the same levels of security which the Australian system and others offered or required?
What other national postal administrations have installed the automated telegraph system, Tress?
What was the capital cost of installing the Tress system?

Did the Director-General in a submission in 1954 to the New South Wales Industrial Commission Inquiry into Automation contend that the Tress system would pay its cost from savings over less than two years; if so, has this prediction eventuated?
What number of Postal Department employees have been (a) retrenched or (b) reduced in classification as a result of the introduction of Tress?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: Teleprinter reperforator switching system were in operation in the United States of America and Canada prior to installation of the Australian system.
The Australian Post Office has not received any reports that the American system compares unfavourably with other systems so far as security is concerned.
Canada, Japan, Argentina and South Africa.
Approximately £900,000.

No, but in 1960 the Director-General released a statement to the Australian Council of Salaried and Professional Associations in connexion with submissions to be made by the Council to the New South Wales Industrial Commission Inquiry into Recent Mechanization and Automation. In part, this statement read: -

Tress is a major step forward in the development of the Australian telegraph service and its adoption is expected to place our telegraph service in the forefront of mechanized systems. For a total capital expenditure of approximately £900,000, savings of up to £500,000 a year should ultimately prove possible.
The installation of Tress has been undertaken progressively since 1959 and is now almost completed. On present indications, the prediction of savings will be achieved.

The reduced staffing requirement under Tress has been met by the adjustment of recruitment prior to introduction of the new equipment and the transfer of surplus staff to other positions. There have been no retrenchments or reductions n classification.
